[Cobalt Strike] can spawn a job to inject into LSASS memory and dump password hashes.
[PoshC2] contains an implementation of [Mimikatz] to gather credentials from memory.
[Medusa Group] has leveraged [Mimikatz] to dump LSASS to harvest credentials.
[BRONZE BUTLER] has used various tools (such as Mimikatz and WCE) to perform credential dumping.
[Windows Credential Editor] can dump credentials.
[APT39] has used Mimikatz, Windows Credential Editor and ProcDump to dump credentials.
In the [Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack], [TEMP.Veles] used Mimikatz.
[Magic Hound] has stolen domain credentials by dumping LSASS process memory using Task Manager, comsvcs.dll, and from a Microsoft Active Directory Domain Controller using [Mimikatz].
[Earth Lusca] has used ProcDump to obtain the hashes of credentials by dumping the memory of the LSASS process.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) used voStro.exe, a compiled pypykatz (Python version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)), to steal credentials.
During [HomeLand Justice](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0038), threat actors dumped LSASS memory on compromised hosts.
[UNC3886](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1048) has used MiniDump to dump process memory and search for cleartext credentials.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has been observed dropping and executing password grabber modules including [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).
[PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used keyloggers that are also capable of dumping credentials.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has used prodump to dump credentials from LSASS.

[Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses credential dumpers such as [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) to extract cached credentials from Windows systems.
[Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used the Farse6.1 utility (based on [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)) to extract credentials from lsass.exe.
[Qilin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1242) can employ an embedded [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) module to dump LSASS memory.

During the [2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0025), [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to capture and use legitimate credentials.
[Pysa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0583) can perform OS credential dumping using [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).

[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources.

[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used its plainpwd tool, a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), and comsvcs.dll to dump Windows credentials from system memory.
[Moonstone Sleet](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1036) retrieved credentials from LSASS memory.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has performed credential dumping with [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and procdump64.exe.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has dumped the lsass.exe memory to harvest credentials with the use of open-source tool [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349).
[Aquatic Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0143) has attempted to harvest credentials through LSASS memory dumping.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has dumped credentials, including by using [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a tool to dump credentials by injecting itself into lsass.exe and triggering with the argument "dig."

[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has used hashdump, [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), Procdump, and the Windows Credential Editor to dump password hashes from memory and authenticate to other user accounts.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) contains an implementation of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to gather credentials from memory.

[Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) leverages [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) to steal credentials.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) for credential dumping.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) uses legitimate Sysinternals tools such as procdump to dump LSASS memory.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can dump password hashes from `LSASS.exe`.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) regularly deploys both publicly available (ex: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)) and custom password retrieval tools on victims.
[Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) has a built-in `procdump` command allowing for retrieval of memory from processes such as `lsass.exe` for credential harvesting.
[Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) contains a module that tries to obtain credentials from LSASS, similar to [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has gathered credentials using [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and ProcDump.
[Play](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1040) has used [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) and the Windows Task Manager to dump LSASS process memory.
[RedCurl](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1039) used [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) to obtain passwords from memory.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) was seen using MimikatzLite to perform credential dumping.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can harvest credentials using [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).
During the [C0032](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0032) campaign, [TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) used Mimikatz and a custom tool, SecHack, to harvest credentials.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) has a module for [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to collect Windows credentials from the victimâ€™s machine.

[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067)'s has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\CurrentVersion\\Run\\.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has maintained persistence using the startup folder.

[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used Registry Run keys to establish automatic execution at system startup.
[Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) adds Registry Run keys to achieve persistence.
[SHIPSHAPE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0028) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.

[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048) has used Registry run keys to establish persistence for the [RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) Trojan and other tools, such as a modified version of TeamViewer remote desktop software.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence.

[Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) has used PowerShell to bypass UAC.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has a function in the initial dropper to bypass Windows UAC in order to execute the next payload with higher privileges.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used a Windows 10 specific tool and xxmm to bypass UAC for privilege escalation.
[Qilin] can bypass standard user access controls by using stolen tokens to launch processes at an elevated security context.
[AutoIt backdoor] attempts to escalate privileges by bypassing User Access Control.
[FinFisher] performs UAC bypass.
[Bad Rabbit] has attempted to bypass UAC and gain elevated administrative privileges.
[Downdelph] bypasses UAC to escalate privileges by using a custom â€œRedirectEXEâ€ shim database.
[Koadic] has 2 methods for elevating integrity. It can bypass UAC through `eventvwr.exe` and `sdclt.exe`.
[Avaddon] bypasses UAC using the CMSTPLUA COM interface.
[QuasarRAT] can generate a UAC pop-up Window to prompt the target user to run a command as the administrator.
[Winnti for Windows] can use a variant of the sysprep UAC bypass.
[WastedLocker] can perform a UAC bypass if it is not executed with administrator rights or if the infected host runs Windows Vista or later.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) uses various techniques to bypass UAC.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) installer can use UAC bypass techniques to install the payload.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has utilized multiple techniques to bypass UAC.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) bypasses user access control by using a DLL hijacking vulnerability in the Windows Update Standalone Installer (wusa.exe).
[Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has bypassed UAC.
An older variant of [PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) performs UAC bypass.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has a command for UAC bypassing.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can use [UACMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0116) for privilege escalation.

[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) can suppress UAC prompts by setting the HKCU\Software\Classes\ms-settings\shell\open\command registry key on Windows 10 or HKCU\Software\Classes\mscfile\shell\open\command on Windows 7 and launching the eventvwr.msc process, which launches [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) with elevated privileges.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has used the Fodhelper UAC bypass technique to gain elevated privileges.
During [Operation Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0006), the threat actors used the malicious NTWDBLIB.DLL and `cliconfig.exe` to bypass UAC protections.
[CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) can bypass UAC using the SilentCleanup task to execute the binary with elevated privileges.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has the ability to bypass UAC to deploy post exploitation tools with elevated privileges.
A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can use a public UAC bypass method to elevate privileges.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can bypass UAC by registering as the default handler for .MSC files.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) has the ability to bypass UAC using a `passuac.dll` file.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) attempts to disable UAC remote restrictions by modifying the Registry.

[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) contains a number of modules that can bypass UAC, including through Window's Device Manager, Manage Optional Features, and an image hijack on the `.msc` file extension.
[AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has presented the user with a UAC prompt to elevate privileges while installing.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can use fileless UAC bypass and create an elevated COM object to escalate privileges.
[KOCTOPUS] will perform UAC bypass either through fodhelper.exe or eventvwr.exe.(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
[Sliver] can leverage multiple techniques to bypass User Account Control (UAC) on Windows systems.(Citation: Cybereason Sliver Undated)
[Patchwork] bypassed User Access Control (UAC).(Citation: Cymmetria Patchwork)
[CHIMNEYSWEEP] can make use of the Windows `SilentCleanup` scheduled task to execute its payload with elevated privileges.(Citation: Mandiant ROADSWEEP August 2022)

[Raspberry Robin] will use the legitimate Windows utility fodhelper.exe to run processes at elevated privileges without requiring a User Account Control prompt.(Citation: RedCanary RaspberryRobin 2022)
[BADHATCH] can utilize the CMSTPLUA COM interface and the SilentCleanup task to bypass UAC.(Citation: BitDefender BADHATCH Mar 2021)
[UACMe] contains many methods for bypassing Windows User Account Control on multiple versions of the operating system.(Citation: Github UACMe)
[Medusa Group] has attempted to bypass UAC using Component Object Model (COM) interface.(Citation: Intel471 Medusa Ransomware May 2025)
[Empire] includes various modules to attempt to bypass UAC for escalation of privileges.(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)
[RCSession] can bypass UAC to escalate privileges.(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has bypassed UAC.(Citation: Mandiant No Easy Breach)

BlackByte enumerated Active Directory information and trust relationships during operations.
Bazar can use Nltest tools to obtain information about the domain.
IcedID used Nltest during initial discovery.
Pikabot will gather information concerning the Windows Domain the victim machine is a member of during execution.
AdFind can gather information about organizational units (OUs) and domain trusts from Active Directory.
Rubeus can gather information about domain trusts.
Akira uses the built-in Nltest utility or tools such as AdFind to enumerate Active Directory trusts in victim environments.
Chimera has nltest /domain_trusts to identify domain trust relationships.
SocGholish can profile compromised systems to identify domain trust relationships.
[Leviathan] performed Active Directory enumeration of victim environments...
[Lotus Blossom] has used tools such as [AdFind] to make Active Directory queries.
[MgBot] includes modules for collecting information on local domain users and permissions.
[Nltest] may be used to enumerate trusted domains by using commands such as nltest /domain_trusts.
[QakBot] can run nltest /domain_trusts /all_trusts for domain trust discovery.
[Earth Lusca] has used [Nltest] to obtain information about domain controllers.
[Brute Ratel C4] can use LDAP queries and nltest /domain_trusts for domain trust discovery.
[BloodHound] has the ability to map domain trusts and identify misconfigurations for potential abuse.
[Latrodectus] can run C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c nltest /domain_trusts to discover domain trusts.
[BADHATCH] can use nltest.exe /domain_trusts to discover domain trust relationships on a compromised machine.
[Storm-0501] has used Windows native utility [Nltest] `nltest.exe` for discovery.
[DUSTTRAP] can identify Active Directory information and related items.
[PoshC2] has modules for enumerating domain trusts.
[Storm-1811] has enumerated domain accounts and access during intrusions.
During the [SolarWinds Compromise], [APT29] used the `Get-AcceptedDomain` PowerShell cmdlet to enumerate accepted domains through an Exchange Management Shell.
[Magic Hound] has used a web shell to execute `nltest /trusted_domains` to identify trust relationships.
[dsquery] can be used to gather information on domain trusts with `dsquery * -filter "(objectClass=trustedDomain)" -attr *`.
[PowerSploit] has modules such as `Get-NetDomainTrust` and `Get-NetForestTrust` to enumerate domain and forest trusts.
[TrickBot] can gather information about domain trusts by utilizing [Nltest].
[FIN8] has retrieved a list of trusted domains by using `nltest.exe /domain_trusts`.
